title: PNC Refund Radar
rawDocument: I. Strategic Identity ● Feature Name: PNC Refund Radar ● Product Pillar: Virtual Wallet / Cash Flow Management ● Target Persona: High-frequency online shoppers (Gen Z/Millennials) who utilize Buy Now, Pay Later or return items frequently. ● The Magic Moment: Receiving a notification the moment a merchant initiates a refund, even before the money hits the ledger, so the user knows they won the dispute or return. II. The Problem Space (Deep Dive) ● The Micro-Friction Event: A user returns a $200 jacket to a retailer. They check their transaction history daily for 7 days. Because the refund date often differs from the return date, they have to scroll back through weeks of data to see if the credit arrived. ● Data Blind Spots: Users cannot see the difference between a Pending Credit and a Settled Credit. They also don't know if a partial refund (e.g., $180 vs $200) is due to a restocking fee or a bank error. ● Psychological Hurdle: Financial Limbo. The user feels they have $200 missing in the world, which prevents them from making other necessary purchases, leading to a feeling of being out of control. ● Existing Workarounds: Users keep screenshots of return receipts or keep Return emails marked as unread in their inbox until they manually verify the credit in the PNC app. ● The Cost of Inaction: High volume of Where is my money? calls to PNC support; customers perceiving the bank as slow even when the delay is on the merchant’s end. III. Strategic Constraints & Inputs ● Integrations: Must pull data from ISO 8583 transaction messaging (specifically looking for Credit indicators) and integrate with the Virtual Wallet Calendar view. ● The North Star Policy: Must adhere to Reg E (Electronic Fund Transfers) regarding the timing of when credits must be made available to the customer. ● The Do-Not-Touch List: The feature should NOT allow the user to spend the refund until the funds are officially settled/cleared, to avoid overdraft risk if the merchant reverses the credit.
summary: The document outlines PNC Refund Radar, a feature designed to eliminate refund uncertainty for high-frequency online shoppers. It identifies pain points around refund tracking, psychological stress, lack of transparency, and operational costs. The strategy focuses on providing real-time refund initiation notifications, distinguishing pending versus settled credits, integrating data with Virtual Wallet, and adhering to regulatory and risk constraints. The opportunity aligns with large market segments such as Gen Z/Millennial shoppers and BNPL users, offering strong differentiation and potential to reduce support costs.

productIdeas: Real-time detection and notification when merchants initiate refunds
Distinguishing pending credits from settled credits within the banking app
Integrating refund visibility into PNC Virtual Wallet's Calendar view
Providing transparency into refund amounts, including partial refunds and reasons
Reducing customer uncertainty by surfacing refund status before funds settle
Traditional banks’ lack of refund‑specific transparency creates a first‑mover opportunity for PNC to define the category and own customer expectations.
Fintechs emphasize spend visibility, not refund lifecycle visibility, leaving a whitespace where PNC can differentiate on emotional reassurance rather than just financial tooling.
Early refund detection can become a signature feature that drives daily active usage of Virtual Wallet by inserting value into a high-frequency, high-anxiety moment.
Competitors’ limited data models around refunds mean PNC can differentiate by providing granularity (partial refunds, reasons, merchant‑level patterns) that others cannot.
Banks currently treat refunds as back-office operational events; shifting them into a customer‑facing experience can reframe PNC as proactive rather than reactive.
By reducing refund‑related support calls, PNC can create a dual advantage—customer satisfaction and operational efficiency—while competitors continue absorbing avoidable support costs.
A strong refund transparency feature can become a differentiator for younger segments who already compare banks based on app experience rather than legacy trust factors.
Competitors lacking refund prediction or expected‑arrival signals give PNC room to develop a unique ‘refund ETA’ capability, similar to package tracking, that others have not yet attempted.

marketSizing.highFrequencyShoppers: Tens of millions of Gen Z and Millennial consumers frequently shop online in the U.S.
marketSizing.bnplUsers: Approximately 70M+ BNPL users in the U.S., a segment with high return and refund volume
marketSizing.ecommerceReturns: E-commerce return volume exceeds $200B annually, indicating widespread refund friction
marketSizing.bankSupportLoad: High call volume related to refund status represents substantial cost savings opportunity

customerSegments: Gen Z and Millennial frequent online shoppers
Buy Now, Pay Later users with recurring returns or disputes
Consumers who monitor cash flow closely using banking apps
Users who experience financial anxiety or uncertainty during refund waiting periods
businessGoals: Reduce call center volume related to refund inquiries
Improve customer perception of speed, transparency, and trust in PNC
Differentiate Virtual Wallet with superior refund intelligence
Increase engagement with the Virtual Wallet calendar and transaction views
Support regulatory compliance while enhancing customer experience
scenarios: User returns an item and receives an immediate notification when the merchant initiates a refund, reducing monitoring anxiety
User sees a pending refund clearly marked in the app, eliminating the need to scroll through historical transactions
Customer receives explanation for partial refunds, reducing confusion and support calls
Refund intelligence integrates with the calendar so upcoming credits are visible in cash flow planning
System prevents premature spending of refunds to avoid overdraft risk and regulatory issues
customerNeeds: Clear visibility into the status of refunds
Separation of pending vs. settled refund credits
Transparency around discrepancies in refund amounts
Reduced uncertainty and psychological stress related to missing funds
A unified place to track returns without manual workarounds
stage1Analysis.competitiveInsights: Most banks do not provide real-time refund initiation visibility or differentiate pending vs settled credits, leaving a competitive gap. Neo-banks and fintechs emphasize transparency but generally focus on spending, not refund tracking. Providing early refund intelligence and integrating it into cash flow tools could position PNC Virtual Wallet as a leader in refund transparency and customer peace-of-mind experiences.

epics.name: Refund Detection Engine
epics.description: Detect refund initiation events from ISO 8583 messages and surface pending credits in real time.

epics.name: Refund Status Transparency
epics.description: Differentiate pending vs settled refunds, display refund details, and clarify partial refund amounts.

epics.name: User Notifications and Alerts
epics.description: Notify users instantly when a refund is initiated and when it settles.

epics.name: Virtual Wallet Calendar Integration
epics.description: Display upcoming pending refunds and settled refunds within the Virtual Wallet calendar view.

epics.name: Risk & Regulatory Compliance Guardrails
epics.description: Ensure no premature spending of pending refunds and maintain Reg E compliance.

userStories.story: As a frequent online shopper, I want the app to notify me when a merchant initiates a refund, so that I don't have to manually monitor my transaction history.
As a user, I want to see a pending refund clearly labeled in my transaction feed, so that I can understand that a credit is on the way.
As a user, I want to know the difference between a pending refund and a settled refund, so that I understand when funds are fully available.
As a user, I want to see partial refund amounts clearly explained, so that I know whether the difference is due to merchant fees or adjustments.
As a user, I want to see my pending refunds appear on the Virtual Wallet calendar, so that I can plan my cash flow.
As a user, I want to receive a notification when my refund settles, so that I know when the funds are ready to use.
As a user, I want to tap a pending refund to view details like merchant, expected amount, and date initiated, so that I have full transparency.
As a user, I want the system to prevent me from spending a pending refund, so that I don't accidentally overdraft if the merchant reverses the credit.
As a user, I want to see the estimated settlement window for a pending refund, so that I understand when to expect the money to fully arrive.
As a user, I want to filter my transaction history to show only refunds, so that I can easily track returns.
As a user, I want to view a history of past refunds including partial refunds, so that I have clarity about past merchant behaviors.
As a user, I want refund notifications to avoid false alarms if the merchant attempts but reverses a refund, so that I trust the system.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a frequent online shopper, I want the app to notify me when a merchant initiates a refund, so that I don't have to manually monitor my transaction history.
criteria: Given a valid refund initiation ISO 8583 message, When the system receives it, Then a push notification is sent to the user's device.
Given a reversed refund message, When the system detects it, Then no notification is sent and the event is suppressed.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want to see a pending refund clearly labeled in my transaction feed, so that I can understand that a credit is on the way.
criteria: Given a detected refund initiation, When the user opens the transaction feed, Then the refund appears with a pending label.
Given no refund messages for the merchant, When user scrolls the feed, Then no pending refund marker appears.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want to know the difference between a pending refund and a settled refund, so that I understand when funds are fully available.
criteria: Given a pending refund, When the user views the transaction detail, Then the status shows Pending.
Given a settled refund, When the user views the transaction detail, Then the status shows Settled.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want to see partial refund amounts clearly explained, so that I know whether the difference is due to merchant fees or adjustments.
criteria: Given a partial refund amount, When the user taps the refund, Then the app explains the discrepancy.
Given no metadata on partial refunds, When user taps the refund, Then the app displays a generic explanation placeholder.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want to see my pending refunds appear on the Virtual Wallet calendar, so that I can plan my cash flow.
criteria: Given a pending refund exists, When the user opens the Calendar view, Then the refund appears on the date initiated.
Given a future settlement estimate, When the user views the calendar, Then the estimated settlement date shows as a tentative event.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want to receive a notification when my refund settles, so that I know when the funds are ready to use.
criteria: Given a settlement message, When the system processes it, Then a settlement notification is sent.
Given a duplicate settlement message, When processed, Then no second notification is sent.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want to tap a pending refund to view details like merchant, expected amount, and date initiated, so that I have full transparency.
criteria: Given a pending refund exists, When the user taps it, Then detail view loads with merchant, amount, date.
Given missing metadata, When tapped, Then the details display placeholders instead of errors.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want the system to prevent me from spending a pending refund, so that I don't accidentally overdraft if the merchant reverses the credit.
criteria: Given a pending refund, When the user attempts to spend beyond available settled funds, Then the system blocks the transaction.
Given a settled refund, When user spends, Then the transaction is allowed normally.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want to see the estimated settlement window for a pending refund, so that I understand when to expect the money to fully arrive.
criteria: Given an estimated window is calculable, When user views pending refund, Then the estimated range is shown.
Given insufficient data for estimation, When viewed, Then the app hides the estimate field.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want to filter my transaction history to show only refunds, so that I can easily track returns.
criteria: Given the user enables refund filter, When viewing the transaction feed, Then only refund entries appear.
Given no refunds exist, When filter is applied, Then an empty state message appears.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want to view a history of past refunds including partial refunds, so that I have clarity about past merchant behaviors.
criteria: Given historic refund data exists, When user views refund history, Then all past refunds appear chronologically.
Given no history exists, When user opens the history view, Then an empty-state message appears.

acceptanceCriteria.storyRef: As a user, I want refund notifications to avoid false alarms if the merchant attempts but reverses a refund, so that I trust the system.
criteria: Given a refund initiation and same-day reversal, When detected, Then no user notification is sent.
Given a refund initiation without reversal, When detected, Then a notification is sent.

mvp: Pending refund label and detail view

assumptions: ISO 8583 messages provide sufficient data to identify refund initiation.
Partial refund reason codes may not always be available from merchants.
Calendar integration requires existing Virtual Wallet APIs.
Notifications follow existing PNC messaging infrastructure.
Pending funds should not be counted in available balance.
Settlement timings vary widely across merchants.

evidence: Synthetic: “I returned a $150 pair of shoes and kept checking my app every morning because I had no idea when the refund would show up.”
Synthetic: “Not knowing if the refund is coming makes me feel like money is just floating out there.”
Synthetic: “I hate having to scroll back a week or more to see if the refund hit.”
feedbackThemes.impact: High emotional stress and frequent app re-checking lead to negative perceptions of PNC’s speed and reliability.
feedbackThemes.opportunity: Provide real-time refund initiation alerts to reduce uncertainty and enhance trust.

feedbackThemes.theme: Lack of Visibility Into Refund Status
evidence: Synthetic: “I never know if something is pending or actually settled—it all looks the same in my transaction list.”
Synthetic: “It’s confusing when a refund doesn’t match the original purchase amount and there’s no explanation.”
Synthetic: “I can’t tell if the merchant started the refund or if the bank is just slow.”
feedbackThemes.impact: Users blame the bank for delays and lack context for discrepancies, causing unnecessary service calls.
feedbackThemes.opportunity: Show clear labeling for pending vs settled refunds and surface reason codes or partial refund explanations.

evidence: Synthetic: “I put off buying groceries because I was waiting for a refund that didn’t show for days.”
Synthetic: “Refunds are part of my weekly cash flow but I can’t plan around them right now.”
Synthetic: “If I knew when the refund was coming, I’d feel more comfortable making other purchases.”
feedbackThemes.impact: Refund uncertainty disrupts budgeting and increases perceived financial instability.
feedbackThemes.opportunity: Integrate expected refunds into the Virtual Wallet calendar for better cash flow forecasting.

evidence: Synthetic: “I keep my return emails unread until the credit shows up in my bank.”
Synthetic: “I screenshot return receipts because the bank app doesn’t help me track refunds.”
Synthetic: “I use notes on my phone to remember how much I’m waiting on.”
feedbackThemes.impact: Customers depend on external tools, weakening the bank’s role in their financial workflow.
feedbackThemes.opportunity: Centralize refund tracking within PNC by surfacing expected refund amounts with timestamps.

evidence: Synthetic: “Every time a refund is late, I call the bank—but half the time the merchant didn’t even start it yet.”
Synthetic: “I assume the bank is slow because I can’t see what’s going on behind the scenes.”
Synthetic: “Support always tells me to ‘wait a few days’ and it’s exhausting.”
feedbackThemes.impact: High volume of unnecessary inbound support calls and user blame misdirected at PNC.
feedbackThemes.opportunity: Surface early merchant-initiated refund signals to reduce calls and reassign accountability.

competitorComparison.weakness: No distinction between pending and settled refunds; no early refund visibility.
competitorComparison.gapWeExploit: Offer predictive and early refund intelligence they lack.

competitorComparison.strength: Robust dispute support and merchant data enrichment.
competitorComparison.weakness: Refund visibility is delayed and lacks explanatory detail.
competitorComparison.gapWeExploit: Provide explanations for partial refunds and real‑time signals.

competitorComparison.weakness: Minimal refund tracking capabilities; poor transparency.
competitorComparison.gapWeExploit: Deliver higher‑resolution refund tracking as a differentiator.

competitorComparison.strength: Good alerts ecosystem and modern UI.
competitorComparison.weakness: Refund notifications focus on settlement only, not initiation.
competitorComparison.gapWeExploit: Push earlier signals and integrate into cash flow planning.

competitorComparison.strength: Fast transaction updates and user‑friendly design.
competitorComparison.weakness: Limited refund detail; no dedicated refund tracking interface.
competitorComparison.gapWeExploit: Provide structured and detailed refund reporting.

competitorComparison.strength: Transparent refund timelines for PayPal‑based purchases.
competitorComparison.weakness: No insight into card‑based or external merchant refund pipelines.
competitorComparison.gapWeExploit: Provide a unified cross‑merchant refund dashboard.

competitorComparison.strength: Strong spend insights and modern UX.
competitorComparison.weakness: Refund information often delayed depending on merchant systems.
competitorComparison.gapWeExploit: Surface ISO 8583 credit indicators faster and more clearly.

competitorComparison.strength: Clear transaction feeds and good user communication.
competitorComparison.weakness: No structured refund timeline or partial refund breakdown.
competitorComparison.gapWeExploit: Add contextual refund explanations and timelines.

trends.trend: Growth of high‑frequency online shopping among Gen Z/Millennials
trends.implication: Refund volume is rising, increasing demand for clarity and speed.

trends.trend: Expansion of Buy Now, Pay Later usage
trends.implication: Refund processes are more complex and fragmented, amplifying the need for centralized tracking.

trends.trend: Shift to real‑time financial data expectations
trends.implication: Users expect instant updates even for processes like refunds traditionally hidden behind settlement cycles.

trends.trend: Rise in customer anxiety around small‑scale financial uncertainty
trends.implication: Services that reduce ambiguity gain disproportionate emotional loyalty.
Early adoption of refund transparency could create durable competitive advantage.

trends.trend: Increased merchant disputes and partial refunds
trends.implication: Explaining refund variances becomes a core UX requirement, not a luxury.

insights: Uncertainty around refund timing creates emotional friction that is disproportionate to the dollar value.
The inability to differentiate pending and settled credits directly results in misattribution of blame to the bank.
Refunds are a meaningful contributor to weekly cash flow planning for heavy online shoppers.
Manual workarounds suggest high user demand for centralized refund visibility.
Early signals from merchant refund initiation are a high‑value, low‑competition area.
opportunities: Deliver real-time refund initiation notifications before settlement.
Label refunds clearly as pending vs settled in the transaction feed.
Integrate expected refunds into Virtual Wallet’s calendar for cash flow clarity.
Provide explanations for partial refunds by surfacing merchant reason codes where available.
Create a dedicated refund status view summarizing all expected credits.
risks: Users may misunderstand pending refunds as spendable funds, increasing overdraft risk.
Merchant data inconsistencies could cause incorrect or premature notifications.
Reg E compliance constraints may limit what can be communicated and when.
Over-reliance on ISO 8583 signals may lead to gaps for merchants with non-standard processing.
If accuracy is low, trust in the feature could erode quickly.
nextResearchSteps: Validate user comprehension of pending vs settled terminology.
Test willingness to rely on early refund signals for financial planning.
Assess expectations around partial refund explanations.
Interview call center agents to map common refund-related complaints.
Prototype information hierarchy for refund tracking surfaces and test with target users.
assumptions: ISO 8583 credit indicators are consistently available for early refund detection.
Users will interpret refund initiation as informational, not guaranteed availability.
Merchants’ refund timelines vary widely and may affect user expectations.
Gen Z/Millennials prefer proactive alerts over passive monitoring.
Clear labeling will reduce support call volume tied to refund confusion.

entryPoints: Refund Details page via pending credit banner
steps: User receives push notification of a newly initiated refund.
User taps notification and is taken to Refund Details screen.
User views refund status: Pending vs Settled, amount, merchant, expected timing.
User returns to Activity view, now showing a Pending Refund row above settled transactions.
User taps into Calendar to view estimated refund arrival in cash-flow planning.
Once settled, user sees updated status and the ledger reflects available funds.
userFlow.description: Flow covers detection of refund initiation, visibility into pending vs settled states, and integration with Calendar for cash-flow clarity.

wireframes.purpose: Alert user instantly when merchant initiates refund.
Show refund status, expected settlement, and partial refund explanations.
microcopy: We’ll notify you when it settles

wireframes.purpose: Surface pending refunds distinctly above settled transactions.
Display estimated refund arrival for cash-flow planning.

usabilityTestScript.task: Identify refund status from push notification
usabilityTestScript.script: You just received a refund notification. Open it and tell me what you believe is happening with your refund.
Navigate to the refund details and explain whether the money is available to spend.
Locate the refund in your transaction list without scrolling back to the original purchase date.
Go to the refund details and describe why the refund amount is less than expected.

usabilityTestScript.task: Use Calendar to understand expected arrival
usabilityTestScript.script: Open the Calendar and show where the refund appears and what it means for your cash flow.

testCases.case: Push notification tap opens correct refund
testCases.expectedResult: Refund Details screen opens with matching merchant and amount

testCases.case: Pending refund clearly distinct from settled
testCases.expectedResult: Pending Refund row is displayed separately and visually different

testCases.steps: Open Refund Details for partial credit
testCases.expectedResult: Reason text displayed, amount difference clear

testCases.steps: Open Calendar after pending refund exists
testCases.expectedResult: Refund marker appears on estimated date
Balance does not change; no access granted to pending funds
Each pending refund shown clearly with no overlap

testCases.case: Refund initiation comes before ledger update
testCases.expectedResult: Refund shown as pending, not yet in balance
User receives update and pending refund disappears with explanation
Drawer displays refund info and link to details

testCases.case: Notification appears only once per initiation
testCases.expectedResult: Only one notification about initiation unless status changes

testCases.steps: View refund details when refund amount is $0

testCases.expectedResult: Amount and reason still readable and clear

testCases.case: Edge case: refund initiated long after purchase
testCases.expectedResult: Pending refund displayed at top, not buried near old purchase
Status flips to Settled; timeline marks completion

testCases.steps: Use screen reader on Refund Details
testCases.expectedResult: Status, amount, and reason fully announced

iteration.feedback: Users confused why pending refund is not spendable.
iteration.change: Add clear label: 'Not available yet' under amount with brief reason tooltip.
Add explicit step: 'Merchant adjusted amount' between initiation and settlement.
Increase visibility with icon + color-coded pending state.

iteration.feedback: Users want quick access back to original purchase.
iteration.change: Add link: 'View original transaction' in Refund Details.

iteration.feedback: Some users misread partial refund explanation.
iteration.change: Add shorter summary line: 'You received less because…' before details.

iteration.feedback: Notification text too long for small screens.
iteration.change: Shorten push copy and move secondary details into the Details screen only.

assumptions: ISO 8583 message provides merchant name, refund amount, and initiation timestamp.
Calendar integration can support estimated, not guaranteed, dates.
Push notifications allowed by user.
Refund reasons provided by merchant or inferred rules.
Pending funds cannot impact available balance.

goals: Track refunds without daily manual checking
Reduce financial anxiety from uncertain refund timing
objections: Concern that alert may not reflect actual settlement timing
Skepticism about bank accuracy on partial refund details
personas.keyMessage: Know exactly when your refund is coming—no more guessing, scrolling, or stress.

personas.name: Evan, The Cash-Flow Manager
goals: Plan upcoming purchases with accurate cash visibility
Quickly understand whether a refund is pending or settled
pains: Inability to distinguish pending vs settled credits
Needing manual reminders to confirm refunds
objections: Worry that early visibility encourages premature spending
personas.keyMessage: Refund Radar gives you the clarity to manage your cash flow without risking overdrafts.

messaging.positioningStatement: PNC Refund Radar is the fastest way to know when your money is on its way back—providing real-time refund initiation alerts, clear pending vs settled visibility, and seamless integration with Virtual Wallet so you can budget with confidence.
benefits: Instant clarity the moment a merchant initiates your refund
Full transparency on pending vs settled credits
Better budgeting with upcoming refunds displayed in Virtual Wallet
proofPoints: ISO 8583 credit detection surfaces refund initiation before settlement
Refund status displayed directly on the Virtual Wallet calendar
Supports Reg E and prevents premature spending for overdraft protection
taglines: Know the moment your money comes back.
Refund clarity you can bank on.

launchGoals: Drive engagement with Virtual Wallet calendar
Increase customer trust and perception of speed
channels: In-app education cards in Virtual Wallet
Push notifications previewing the new refund experience
Social posts highlighting transparency and control
Branch and call center scripts for top refund FAQs
gtmPlan.rollout: Begin with opt-in beta for high-frequency return customers, expand to phased rollout across Virtual Wallet users, then general availability to all eligible accounts.
risks: Users misunderstand pending status as spendable funds
False positives if ISO 8583 indicators vary by merchant

releaseNotes.customerFacing: Introducing PNC Refund Radar: Get notified the moment a merchant initiates your refund, see pending refunds clearly marked in your transaction history, and view upcoming refunds in your Virtual Wallet calendar. Track your money with confidence—no more waiting or scrolling.
releaseNotes.internal: Refund Radar uses ISO 8583 credit indicators to detect refund initiation events and display pending vs settled credits. Funds remain non-spendable until official settlement to maintain Reg E and overdraft protections. Support teams should reinforce that pending refunds reflect merchant actions but may be reversed.

stakeholderComms.execs: Refund Radar launches a differentiated transparency feature that reduces refund-related support calls, strengthens customer trust, and amplifies Virtual Wallet’s cash-flow leadership. This tool positions PNC as the first major bank to offer early refund intelligence.
stakeholderComms.engineering: Launch includes ISO 8583 credit detection, pending vs settled differentiation, and Virtual Wallet calendar integration. Ensure accurate mapping of credit indicators and guardrails preventing spend until settlement. Monitor merchant variability and edge-case reversals.
stakeholderComms.support: Customers will now see refunds as soon as merchants initiate them. Reinforce that pending refunds are informational only and not yet spendable. Partial refund discrepancies may be due to merchant restocking or fee policies. Encourage checking the transaction detail view for more context.

assumptions: ISO 8583 refund initiation indicators will be reliably available from most merchants
Users prefer visibility even if funds aren’t available yet
Notification delivery occurs without latency
Calendar integration can support pending credit objects
